dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET DAWN
dialogues.text: A grainy, low-resolution view of a dusty dirt road. We're low, just inches off the sun-washed ground, and moving fa ZOOMING down a street littered with the refuse of war: sp munitions, rubber bits, animal waste -- all of which, fro this odd, jarring perspective, looks gigantic, monstrous. We approach a crumpled COKE CAN, the white ‘C’ growing enormous on the screen, filling the screen like a skyscra SMASH into the can and barrel ahead. A RAG flutters, blocks our view, then flies away as we po over a bump, catching air and a flash of the horizon line BRIGHT SUN, then landing hard and continue zipping down t dusty road.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET
dialogues.text: A rushed, disorderly evacuation. Iraqi POLICE and SOLDIER herd civilians away from some unseen danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A remote controlled TALON ROBOT (about a quarter million dollars of military-grade bomb squad electronics, aka ‘th bot’) whose SMALL VIDEO CAMERA we have been watching, dri down the side of the road on a pair of treads. Across the street, an Iraqi BUTCHER wearing a bloody whi smock resists being moved from his outdoor stand, which consists of little more than goat carcasses hung on metal hooks. From all sides, American military arrive in armored TROOP CARRIERS, disgorging teams of U.S. ARMY INFANTRY SOLDIERS shout “secure the area’, ‘watch your six,’ ‘stop traffic’ etc.

dialogues.speaker: BAGHDAD, 2004
dialogues.text: This is all taking place in a densely populated, very noi section of Baghdad; the SOUND of far off GUNSHOTS and CAL prayer magnify the turmoil of a metropolis in the midst o occupation/insurgency/civil war.

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET DAWN
dialogues.text: The BUTCHER, furious with the way he’s being pushed aroun is forcibly removed from his shop by several IRAQI SOLDIE

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET DAWN
dialogues.text: Via the low-angle video camera we glimpse a herd of GOATS scampering through frame. BURKA-clad WOMEN and OLD MEN in traditional garb flee the scene. Several more U.S. INFANTRY SOLDIERS move a few straggler PEDESTRIANS away from a trash pile and the TALON ROBOT. View momentarily blocked by STATIC INTERFERENCE. But when the screen clears, we close in on one particular TRASH PILE topped with a white plastic garbage bag. Whatever it is that has everyone so afraid lies inside th bag.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MIDDLE EASTERN STREET
dialogues.text: The TALON ROBOT pokes around the bag and the trash pile w its mechanical VISE GRIP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to a parked Humvee, THREE EOD (Explosive Ordnance Disposal, aka Bomb Squad) SOLDIERS crouch over a laptop computer screen showing an image of the TRASH PILE. Working the joystick on the laptop is SERGEANT J. T. SANB a type-A jock, high school football star, cocky, outgoing ready with a smile and quick with a joke... or, if you prefer, a jab to the chin. Think Muhammad Ali with a rifl

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I think we have touchdown.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: The robot grinds the dirt, edging closer to the bag.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Standing near Sanborn, SERGEANT FIRST CLASS MATT THOMPSON wipes the sweat on his brow. Although he’s the team leade every inch the professional soldier working a routine mission, Thompson’s normally rock-solid nerves are waveri in the punishing desert heat. While nibbling on a SNICKERS candy bar, Thompson glances his shoulder noting potential threats: a WOMAN in a VEIL then TWO MALES in a window - all of whom are watching him with inscrutable expressions. Thompson turns back to Sanborn and the task at hand:

dialogues.speaker: LAPTOP SCREEN
dialogues.text: We glide across the pile. Flies buzzing. Puffs of dust and fluttering plastic. Advancing slowly, inch by inch, to the edge for our first glimpse inside the bag:

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Hello mamma. Zoom in on the nose cone of the shell.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (re: the robot’s camera) Push it in.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: What do you mean - you can’t? Pretend it’s your dick.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: How about I pretend it’s your dick?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: You'll never get it in if you do that. Let me try. A THIRD SOLDIER, clearly enjoying the two men he’s with, leans in for a better look. This is SPECIALIST OWEN ELDRI the youngest of the group, impressionable, vulnerable, ye quite capable of showing surprising backbone.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Give me a second.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: No. Time is up. My dick. They change places. Thompson now on the controls. They ca see protruding from the rusty shell the tell-tale wire of Improvised Explosive Device (IED).

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: See that?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Nice one-five-five.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s going to do some damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling over his shoulder) Hey Eldridge, we’re going to need a charge. Eldridge is already on it, approaching with the four bloc of C4 plastic explosive. He’s done this enough to know wh they need.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Got it. Figured four blocks, gives you about twenty pounds of bang total. Are we going to be far enough away? Thompson takes stock of the situation. We see the IED in distance -- far, far away.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: The blast is going to roll out there (pointing) the shell will probably kick out there (pointing), and most of the shrapnel is going to rain up in a beautiful umbrella pattern. Some smaller pieces and shell fragments will come out this way but we’ll be okay if we are behind the Humvee. Bring the bot back and we will load up.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No problem. Bot is moving.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE NEAR PLASTIC BAG
dialogues.text: The bot dutifully makes its return voyage back to the men

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: A crowd of angry pedestrians is being held in place by a Iraqi soldiers, but when one soldier turns aside to help old man, the cantankerous BUTCHER slips past and dashes b to his store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eldridge clips a make-shift wagon to a hitch on the rear the robot. Inside the wagon, he’s placed an array of C4. Sanborn asks “ready?,” Eldridge replies “good to go.”

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Alright. Wagon is set. Bot moves. The bot returns downrange, towing the cart and a coil of unspooling detonation wire, which Eldridge is holding. When... the HERD of GOATS from earlier circles back and momentari impedes the robot.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Goats! Blow those bastards up.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: The robot churns down the now empty street.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Thompson scans his surroundings, finds a third IRAQI MALE watching him from a nearby balcony. A flicker of concern flashes across his face.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: The robot hits a bump and a rock jams in the wagon’s whee and breaks the lock nut, popping the wheel and causing th whole rig to grind to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Everyone cringes.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: The wagon is stranded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanborn wiggles the stick. It’s not happening.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Wagon is having a bad day.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (to Eldridge) Did you build that?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: No, the U.S. Army did.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: It looks like I’m going down there.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What, you don’t like waiting around this beautiful neighborhood? Thompson ruefully tosses his helmet into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: I love it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Sanborn unpacks “THE SUIT.” A state-of-the-art contraptio that looks like an astronaut suit and helmet crossed with Michelin Man. Because of its weight and complexity it tak two men to put it on - or one Sanborn. Sanborn kneels down and guides Thompson’s feet into the suit’s black boots, then lashes up a series of Velcro str to secure the armor, like a squire working on a knight. Thompson twists to get his chest protector on. Eyes tight brow furrowed, squints into the far distance. That's goin to be a mean motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m going to make my approach. This area looks okay. No power-lines. Clean line of sight. If it looks alright when I get down there, I’m going to plug it in and we'll just BIP it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOMPSON (cont'd) I want them to know if they’re going to leave a bomb on the side of the road, we’re going to blow up their little fucking road.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: I’m craving a hamburger, is that strange?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Not for you. Sanborn seals Thompson’s helmet with a glass plate while Eldridge attaches a breathing hose.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (headset from inside the helmet) This is Blaster One.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Roger that. Blaster One. You’re good to go. Thompson begins the lonely walk toward the bomb. Sanborn checks on the TWO IRAQI males in the balcony by glassing them with his M4 scope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are smiling. Low threat.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: Constrained by the eighty-pound suit, sweat in his eyes, Thompson LUMBERS down the road, emitting dust clouds with every step.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (headset) Nice and hot in here... One fifty.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Roger that. A hundred and fifty meters. An excited, blustering YOUNG IRAQI MALE, having just exit nearby building, approaches Sanborn with his hand extende greeting:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Hi, where are you from? Sanborn shakes his head, raises his rifle. The young man maintains a nervous grin.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: California? New York? Now they are standing close to each other.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Get out of here man.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: This ain’t a fucking meet-and- greet. GET OUT OF HERE! Sanborn shoves the young man in the chest hard enough to nearly knock him over.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Go! The man skulks away, offended and confused. Eldridge -- who is about thirty feet away and inspecting burned out car -- notices this interaction out of the cor of his eye and keys his walkie to Sanborn:

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Making friends again, Sanborn?  10

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (smiling) All day long.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: Thompson walks on. The desert sun glints off a nearby car and momentarily bleaches his mask bright white. A YOUNG GIRL with an INFANT BABY in her arms appears in a off doorway, then withdraws out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Eldridge and Sanborn are at the ready, scanning the area watching Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: Thompson: careful footfalls on sand.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (headset) Twenty five.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Sanborn wearily keys the walkie.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) Roger, twenty five. You are now in the kill zone.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (headset) Thanks for reminding me. Eldridge nods. Everything progressing nice and easy.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE NEAR PLASTIC BAG
dialogues.text: Thompson stands over the blasting caps, picks them up and heads for the bomb.  11

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (headset) Dets look okay.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (over walkie) Roger that. Thompson carefully lays the C4 on top of the IED.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (headset) Laying on the charge. (beat) ) Good to go, coming back. Thompson gets up, looks around at the empty road under he guard. The war has stopped for him and he knows it. Thompson begins to walk back uprange, looking carefully a the ground around him.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (headset) Five meters.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) Five meters, roger that.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Sanborn and Eldridge lower their rifles.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE NEAR PLASTIC BAG
dialogues.text: Thompson carefully nudges a Coke can out of the way of hi boots.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Eldridge, killing time, turns to Sanborn as they both wat Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Hey Sanborn, you know what this place needs?  12 Looking around the war torn dirt street, the mud colored buildings, and endless expanse of dust and sand. Nothing brown on brown.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Grass.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: We gonna start our grass business?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: That's right. I’m going to sell the grass -- and you're going to cut it. It’s going to be called ‘Sanborn and Sons.’ We’ll be rich.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I like that. Crab grass, St. Augustine, I’m a scholar on this shit. How about this? You sell it -- I fertilize it. THOMPSON O.S. (headset) Twenty five.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) Twenty five. Roger that. Eldridge squints into the sun. Out of the corner of his eye he sees movement in the butc shop and raises his carbine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BUTCHER is holding a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Hey Sanborn -- Butcher shop - two o'clock! Dude has a phone!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Make him put it down --  13 Eldridge runs toward the butcher shop. Sanborn raises his scope but Eldridge is blocking his lin fire and he can’t get a shot.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (shouting, waving his gun) Hey - put that down-- The BUTCHER nods and puts up his hand as if to say, ‘give a minute.’

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: Thompson senses trouble:

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (headset) Why is Eldridge running? Come on guys, talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Eldridge runs hard

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Drop the phone! Sanborn bolts sideways, trying to maneuver around Eldridg a clear sight line--

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (shouting to Eldridge) PUT DOWN THE CELL PHONE! Burn him! Eldridge burn him! Eldridge, legs pumping, flicks the rifle safety--

dialogues.speaker: BUTCHER SHOP
dialogues.text: The Butcher smiles. Gives Eldridge the thumbs up sign. His other handing dials the phone.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE
dialogues.text: Sanborn sprinting but still can’t find a shooting angle. Eldridge is on fire:  14

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: Now Thompson starts to run. Terror in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prevented from locking aim on the butcher by two telephon polls.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCHER SHOP
dialogues.text: The Butcher smiles back at Eldridge ECU: the Butcher's eyes. ECU: his thumb on send button of the cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: Thompson running full out now when

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: -- A giant billowing fireball bursts from the bomb -- flattening Thompson -- blood splatters the inside of his helmet. Then: -- a secondary explosion erupts -- spewing dust and a wave of particulate matter -- enveloping Eldridge and Sanborn in a coarse cloud of debris. -- we stay on the blast’s aftermath as the last dust roil out in slow motion and -- floats silently over Thompson’s slain body  15

dialogues.speaker: INT CAMP VICTORY WAREHOUSE MORTUARY AFFAIRS
dialogues.text: An officious young MORTUARY AFFAIRS SOLDIER opens the woo lid of a very white large box. Inside, wrapped in plastic, are the remains of a soldier' life: a pair of boots, a toothbrush, a comb, an American flag. Sanborn stares. Struggling to find meaning in the objects Now we see that he’s standing in a large warehouse, the mortuary affairs office, which is filled with rows and ro of many other identical white boxes.

dialogues.speaker: MORTUARY SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Anywhere is good. Sanborn gently places Thompson’s dog tags in the box.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Is that everything?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Yeah. The white box closes. Latches secure the lid. And that’s that. The soldier walks away. Sanborn grips the box. He does not let go.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY DAY
dialogues.text: Sanborn trudges across a camp clearing which is bounded b the barracks and rows of identical aluminum trailers.

dialogues.speaker: INT TRAILER
dialogues.text: Inside a darkened standard-issue military trailer Ministr BLASTING, rattling the walls. Sanborn knocks on the door, hears “yeah, it’s open, come and steps inside.  16 He’s greeted by a MAN holding a roofing hammer in one han and a cigarette in the other. This is SERGEANT FIRST CLAS WILLIAM JAMES, his new boss. Sanborn extends his hand and they shake.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Sergeant James? J.T. Sanborn, my man.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Call me Will.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Welcome to Bravo Company and welcome to Camp Victory.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Camp Victory? I thought this was Camp Liberty.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No, they changed the name about a week ago. ‘Victory’ sounds better. An awkward silence ensues allowing us to get a better loo James. Though a former U.S. Army Ranger in his early thirties, fit and good-looking, one of the lucky ones, he possesses an unusual demeanor. In a world of outgoing you men, James seems markedly self-absorbed. Sanborn notices trait instantly and is puzzled by it. The truth is that a so many years down range, racking up kills and disarming bombs, James has lost some of the ability and most of the need to connect to other people. Right now, however, James is doing his best to act like a regular nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Alright. Well I guess I’m in the right place. (Beat) As long as you are here, could you give me a hand with this? James jerks his head to a window covered with a board of plywood. He walks over to it and starts removing the wood motioning for Sanborn to grab one end of the board.  17

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Maybe you shouldn’t take this down. We get a lot of mortars at night here. The plywood helps stop the lateral frag from coming through. That’s why it’s up there.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It’s not going to stop a mortar from coming through the roof -- you know. Besides, I like the sunshine...(awkwardly) I’m sorry about Thompson, I heard he was a good tech.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was, and he was a great team leader too.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to fill his shoes. I'm just going to do my best.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Appreciate it. Although Sanborn is almost warming to his new Sergeant, J has reached his intimacy limit. He cranks the music, grabs his still-burning cigarette, a flops down on the bed -- all in one surprisingly fluid motion. Then announces cheerfully:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Home sweet home.

dialogues.speaker: INT HUMVEE CAMP VICTORY
dialogues.text: Sanborn is behind the wheel. James is in the passenger se Eldridge is in the back seat. Looking through the Humvee window, we drive past a long l of Ml Abrams battle tanks. They’re neatly parked and gathering sand on all horizontal surfaces.  18

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Aren’t you glad the Army has all these tanks parked here, just in case the Russians come and we have to have a big tank battle.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I'd rather be on the side with the tanks, just in case.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: But they don’t do anything here. Anybody comes alongside the Humvee, we're dead. Anybody even looks at you funny, we’re dead. Pretty much, the bottom line, is if you're in Iraq you're dead. How’s a fucking tank supposed to stop that?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up, Owen.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Sorry. Just trying to scare the new guy. James shrugs this off:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I saw a little bit in Afghanistan.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY/BAGHDAD OUTSKIRTS MORNING
dialogues.text: The Humvee moves out of the base and into the outskirts o the teeming city.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 38

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Hey Owen -- watch the fucking road. The Humvee edges close to a cluster of cars. Eldridge mov up to the gunner’s seat on top of the Humvee.  19

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: Eldridge has a collection of half-empty water bottles tha keeps in the gunner’s nest. He throws a water bottle at the car in front of him. It smashes into the car’s rear windshield. A passenger inside spins, enraged. He sees the Humvee. Settles for a one finger salute for the American.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Imshee -- Imshee !

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: The Humvee grinds to a stop in a ghetto overflowing with trash, with more mud dwellings that look as beaten down a the people. James is first out, lighting another cigarette. Sanborn comes up behind him. Eldridge climbs out of the turret. They are now completely out in the open, feet on Iraqi ground, where anything can happen. Eldridge begins turning suspicious bits of plastic over w the tip of his boots.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (looking around at the empty street) Where are the guys who called this in? James walks on down the street. Sanborn and Eldridge exchange a glance ‘what the hell,’ a follow him. Meanwhile, in the background, Iraqi civilians go about th daily life.  20

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Victory Main, Victory Main, this is Blaster Mike. Interrogative, do you have an updated position? DISPATCH O.S. (over walkie) This is Victory Main. Negative. Figures to follow. Grid 3453.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Well, that’s exactly where I am and I don’t see anybody in fatigues. DISPATCH O.S. Give me a second to confirm. That visual is 3453. James, Sanborn and Eldridge continue their slow walk down street. Around a corner, an empty Humvee comes into view.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We got a Humvee. On the other side of the street, Sanborn rounds the corne approaching the Humvee. He shouts in case someone is insi

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Friendly! But there is nobody to hear him. The truck is empty. Eldridge looks inside the vehicle, checking for blood. James sees a tiny American flag being waved in the window a nearby building, and heads over to it.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (scared) They abandoned their vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (scared too) We got an empty Humvee over here!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Got it!  21

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT BAGHDAD BUILDING DAY
dialogues.text: James peers into a garden where a half dozen young SOLDIE are resting and trying not to look afraid, and one SERGEA CARTER is trying not to look embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Morning boys. Don’t tell me the bomb is in there with you.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT CARTER
dialogues.text: Let’s step outside, I’1l show you what’s going on. He moves into the open and points down the block.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT CARTER
dialogues.text: Down the block, about 20 meters this side of the mosque, East side of the street, one of our informants saw wires in a rubble pile - possible IED. I trust this guy, I know him. You want to talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I‘ll handle it. Keep your guys back. (to Eldridge) Specialist! Bring up the Humvee! Sanborn is already unloading the robot.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Break out the suit.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What about the bot?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What? Don’t you want us to get the bot down there to see what it looks like?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’ll handle it.  22

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: It’s kind of tight down here, James. James grins. Sanborn shoots Eldridge a look. Is he a new or what?

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Sanborn and Eldridge kneel before James, buckling on the suit.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: You know you don’t have to go down there, man, we already have the bot half way out.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It will be alright. Sanborn puts the helmet on.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: First day, I was thinking you might want to take it easy. Now enclosed in the suit, James is ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Let’s rock ‘n roll. James heads downrange, a jaunty bounce to his step. In stark contrast to Thompson’s cautious, lumbering gait, seems eager, almost happy, to approach the bomb. The guys watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: He’s a rowdy boy.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: He’s reckless.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET
dialogues.text: Without warning, James tosses a round metal canister, a s grenade, into the middle of the street. ECU: canister jets explode, propelling a billowing cloud gray smoke.  23

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: Sanborn looks on in confusion as the dense smoke fills th street, obscuring his view of James.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) Blaster One, what’s going on? No answer. James disappears into the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) Blaster One, what are you doing? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) Blaster one, this is Blaster Mike. What’s with the smoke on the side of the road? No answer. SANBORN O.S. (walkie) Hey James, can you hear me? What’s with the smoke? JAMES O.S. (headset ) Creating a diversion. Sanborn can no longer see James through the smoke. He climbs up on top of the Humvee to get a better look. B he gets only a partial view.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) From what? Is there a threat? (to Eldridge) Get up on that wall. Tell me what you see, Specialist! Eldridge leaps onto a nearby narrow stone wall, feet precariously balanced.  24

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I got him. He’s walking downrange.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) James, the smoke is killing my visibility. Where are you in relation to the IED? Are you within 100 meters, yet?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) Hell, I don’t know. I’1l let you know when I’m standing over it. We see the world from James’ point of view: the city take an intense, dreamy hue as if somehow we're in some sort o fugue state. James walks on and the world returns to normal as he near intersection guarded on either side by a HUMVEE and sever SOLDIERS, when... Suddenly a red-and-white TAXI swerves past the SOLDIERS o the left side of the intersection. The soldiers take cover and shout contradictory commands “Stop the car” “Get Down Don’t Move! Back up! Out of the vehicle!” The TAXI BRAKES in front of James.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: Sanborn and Eldridge can hear the shouting but the linger smoke still obscures their sight.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (shouting to Sanborn) Car! Car! A car stopped in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET/INTERSECTION
dialogues.text: James’ headset barks to life:  25 SANBORN O.S. (headset) James, come back now. James pulls a pistol from his holster, aims it at the car

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (over walkie) EOD has a nine on the Haji in the car. Should I send back up?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) I got it. DRIVER’S FACE Impossible to discern whether he’s simply an annoyed taxi driver -- or a Jihadi on a suicide mission.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie to soldier) Negative, negative. You’re too close, the blast will come up the street. Stand down. Stay behind the corner. EOD has the situation under control.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET/INTERSECTION
dialogues.text: James aims at the windshield. The driver is impassive. Soldiers shout, “get out of the car!” James SHOOTS two rounds into the dirt near the car’s fron tire. The Driver remains still. Staring back. James gestures with the pistol.  26

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It’s that way...Back. James FIRES -- -- smashing the windshield into a million shards of glass But the car doesn't budge. Now James jams his gun into the driver’s forehead.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Three, four rounds fired. The nine is now pressing into the Haji’s forehead.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: The driver slowly shifts into reverse and eases the taxi to the soldiers. Soldiers rush the car, yank the driver out and pound him roughly to the ground. The taxi driver is zip tied and dragged away.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into mic) If he wasn’t an insurgent he sure as hell is now.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: James resumes his walk, noting possible threats -- a MAN window down the road, TWO KIDS in another window.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET/RUBBLE PILE IED
dialogues.text: One of a million in this city. James draws near. Two wire protrude from the mess. Moment of decision. Moving quickly, James removes rubble and trash to expose wires and the artillery shells.  27 He kneels down into the rubble pile. Touches the bomb. Then with great care, he removes the blasting cap from th bomb, making sure that it doesn’t make contact with the m edges of the artillery shell. He cuts one wire leading to the blasting cap. Then he flips the artillery round over and cuts the other wire.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) We're done. Good to go.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Come down, Specialist.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Roger. Eldridge jumps from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE
dialogues.text: James stands and uses his big boot to clear more rubble, revealing: Another wire snaking out of the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) Got a wire. Hang on.. James traces this wire, pulling it out of the ground, inc inch, like extracting a buried root. The more he pulls, the more wire gets revealed. It doesn’t seem to end.

dialogues.speaker: BALCONY
dialogues.text: Overhead, a YOUNG FACTORY WORKER on a high balcony studie James as he unearths the wire.  28

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET/RUBBLE PILE IED
dialogues.text: James, still pulling the wire, comes to a length that end a bundle of wires that spider out in several different directions.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) Secondary! He pulls on this bundle and unearths a second IED. Then he finds a third IED. Then a fourth bomb. Then realizes he’s surrounded by a ring of IEDs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the daisy-chain. One of the deadlier forms of IED

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (to Eldridge) Off the wall, Owen! (to soldiers) Get behind something. Find cover. Soldiers scrambling to find concrete to hide behind.

dialogues.speaker: BALCONY
dialogues.text: The factory worker leaves his position and heads down the stairs. We follow him walking down the stairs, intercut with: James working on the bombs individually. ECU: James' helmet - glass clouding over from condensatio losing visibility. ECU: blasting cap EcU: feet on stairs ECU: knife tip separates the wire.  29

dialogues.speaker: INT BUILDING STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: The factory worker is now on a landing, still heading dow

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET
dialogues.text: James notices the worker coming down and quickens his pac

dialogues.speaker: INT BUILDING STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: The worker matches James’ accelerated movements, and is n rushing down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET
dialogues.text: The worker reaches the bottom of the stairs, opens the building’s front door, and steps into the street. He looks at James. James shows him the last blasting cap, indicating that th bombs have all been rendered safe. The worker reveals nothing. He turns and steps down an alley. As he goes he drops a 9 volt battery. We find a WIRE TERMINAL attached to the alley wall, where a different day the battery would have been connected to initiate the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: James strides uprange. Eldridge isn’t sure what to make o James. Sanborn is, but not ready to show it. Sanborn unstraps the Velcro on James’ bomb suit, yanking roughly. This gets James attention.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That wasn’t too bad, for our first time working together. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think working together is I talk to you. And you talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Are we going on a date, Sanborn? Sanborn stands face-to-face with James.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No, we're going on a mission. And it’s my job to keep you safe, so we can keep going on missions.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hey, this is combat. 30 James pats Sanborn on the shoulder, moves to the Humvee f Marlborough. Sanborn and Eldridge confer out of ear-shot.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: It’s just thirty nine days.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Thirty eight. Assuming we survive today.

dialogues.speaker: PRELAP
dialogues.text: Electronic GRUNTS of a first-person shooter video game.

dialogues.speaker: INT HEAD SHED SIDE OFFICE
dialogues.text: In a small recreation area, Eldridge, on a couch, plays G of War on a flat screen TV. LT. COL. JOHN CAMBRIDGE, a combat stress therapist, enter

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s mister “Be all that you can be.” What’s up, doc?

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Not much. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I’m good. I had a question about that song, though. What if all I can be is dead on the side of an Iraqi road? I think it’s logical. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 ELDRIDGE (cont'd) This is a war. People die all the time. Why not me?

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: You got to stop obsessing. Change the record in your head. Think about other things. Right now, what are you thinking about?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: You want to know what I’m thinking about?

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Yes. Eldridge picks up his M4 rifle, which had been resting on couch, and puts his finger on the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: This is what I’m thinking about. Here’s Thompson dead. (Now he dry fires. CLICK. He snaps the slide back.) Here, he’s alive. Finger back on safe. He dry fires again.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: He’s dead. He’s alive.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT DAY
dialogues.text: Midday in Iraq. The heat is oppressive, biblical. James is walking around the base when he’s stopped by a y Iraqi KID selling pirated DVDs. The kid, whose name is BECKHAM, is a street savvy punk.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Hey, wassup my nigger? You cool or not? You want to buy the cool shit? The tight shit? No? Fuck you! (he targets James) Hey nigger, buy some DVDs? New releases. Very good.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: One for five, two for nine.  32

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (having fun) Three for twelve.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Three for thirteen. And for you, no tax.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No tax? Alright.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: You're a smart shit, you know. You're not like those stupid fuck face shits.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m a smart guy? You’re a smart kid. Give me your best one.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Here you go. This is the best shit. James pays. Offers a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Keep the change. Want a cigarette? Are you kidding? You shouldn't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: INT CAMP VICTORY SHOWER STALLS NEXT MORNING
dialogues.text: Sanborn is shaving in a mirror, otherwise dressed for com and ready to go. James shuffles in wearing a T-shirt and boxer shorts, loo like he just woke up. James starts to brush his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you about something before we roll out again.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Yesterday -- that was not cool.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I know. You’1l get it.  33 Sanborn wipes his face, trying to stay calm, notices a ta on James’ forearm.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: You were a Ranger? I was in intelligence seven years before EOD. We ran combat missions in every shit hole on the planet. (beat) So I’m pretty sure I can figure out a redneck piece of trailer trash like you. James grins.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Looks like you’re on the right track.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT HUMVEE UNITED NATIONS TEMPORARY HEADQUARTERS MORN
dialogues.text: The men drive into a parking lot teeming with people on t run, hundreds of UN EMPLOYEES, mostly white, many dressed business suits, flee the United Nations building. Parked beside the building is a blue sedan.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER
dialogues.text: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 37 The Humvee passes through a roadblock, stops, and James g out to talk to an IRAQI SERGEANT. Due to his current position in the parking lot, James can see the blue sedan that everyone is running from.

dialogues.speaker: IRAQI SERGEANT
dialogues.text: It’s behind the wall.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Did you see any wires? Any smoke?

dialogues.speaker: IRAQI SERGEANT
dialogues.text: No. I didn’t look.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: So how do you know it’s a bomb?  34

dialogues.speaker: IRAQI SERGEANT
dialogues.text: The car has been parked there illegally and the suspension is sagging, so there’s definitely something heavy in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Why don’t you peek inside and tell me what you see?

dialogues.speaker: IRAQI SERGEANT
dialogues.text: You want me to go close to it? In Arabic: you crazy piece of shit!

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING NEAR SEDAN MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: James now dressed in the bomb suit walks beside the Humve towards the blue sedan. Workers continue to stream out of the building, hurrying faster down a flight of stairs when they see James in the bomb suit. James comes to within twenty feet of the blue sedan. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: BALCONY
dialogues.text: On a third-floor balcony, unseen by the soldiers, a INSUR SNIPER takes aim.

dialogues.speaker: SEDAN
dialogues.text: -- a SHOT rings out -- bullet strikes the car -- it bursts into flames -- a plume of flame rushes out from the gas tank, like a blowtorch -- we see the flames through James’ helmet.  35

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET NEAR UN BUILDING
dialogues.text: “It’s coming from over here”, shout INFANTRY on the groun outside the building as they FIRE M4s at the sniper’s balcony. Their bullets hit concrete, missing the sniper. A TEAM of SOLDIERS charges inside the building.

dialogues.speaker: SEDAN
dialogues.text: James backs away from the fire, toward Sanborn who is now running toward him with a fire extinguisher. Eldridge fol just behind Sanborn.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Sanborn passes James a fire-extinguisher to James.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I got top cover!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That's a negative, Specialist. Eldridge stay with me. Sanborn, you take top cover. It takes Sanborn an instant to process the insult: top co in this case, is the junior man’s job. Shaking his head, Sanborn runs to the building. Eldridge positions himself at the top of a staircase, hunkered down behind a low concrete wall.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: James sprays the extinguisher into the roaring fire. Flam lick his suit.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Sanborn pounds up a long flight of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Gaining control of the fire.  36

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Charges through the rooftop door and runs to the edge of roof.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: The fire is nearly out, the car a smoking ruin, dusted wi white fire retardant powder.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: At the edge of the roof, looking down over James and Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (walkie) Blaster Mike in position.

dialogues.speaker: INT SEDAN
dialogues.text: James stops. He’s done. The fire is out. He looks up at Sanborn, nods. Then he wipes the car’s blackened window and looks inside the bad news.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Scans his surrounding, noting potential threats in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE/STREET
dialogues.text: A salty officer, COLONEL REED, whose uniform shimmers wit military bling and Army skill patches, crosses the street a spot where an Army medic is treating the now badly woun SNIPER. Other SOLDIERS in Reed’s troop stand nearby.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: (to medic) What have you got?  37

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Through and through to the chest but I got him stable.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: (smiling) He’s not going to make it.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: If we’re leaving in fifteen minutes we got a survivable wound, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: (giving an order to Soldier 1) He’s not going to make it. The Colonel turns away. Soldiers crowd around the MEDIC, blocking our view. We HEAR TWO SHOTS, killing the sniper -

dialogues.speaker: ROOF
dialogues.text: The shots echo on the roof. Sanborn spins. Looks down to James.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SEDAN
dialogues.text: James tries to use a crow bar to pry open the trunk but t fails. So he kicks the trunk with the bar, smashing it, until finally it squeaks open, revealing... a_trunk full of South African 155 rounds, linked with det cord. James is so taken aback that he drops the crowbar. Then he pulls the bomb suit’s quick release tab. The bomb suit falls away. Then he takes off his helmet.  38

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) What is he doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: There’s enough bang in here to send us all to Jesus. If I’m going to die, I want to die comfortable. James passes the helmet to Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I need my kit and my cans.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: Sanborn stares down at James and the car. Great.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) I'm getting his kit and cans. (beat) Cover me, please. Eldridge runs to get the equipment, while James finishes removing his suit. Sanborn watches all this. Across the street, a young IRAQI MAN with a_ consumer VID CAMERA is also watching. He goes unnoticed.  39 Eldridge returns with the kit, hands it to James. James approaches the car and shines his flashlight into the tru Smoke. Wires. Bombs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into mic) Got a lot of det cord. Electrical. He snips a wire.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into mic) I’m going to look for the initiator.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Nods, feeling vulnerable and exposed on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: James gets into the back seat, presses the upholstery.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into mic) It’s not in the back seat, I don’t think. He rips the upholstery with his knife. Tearing out foam. no wires.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into mic) Nope. It’s not in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: Sanborn sees a YOUNG MAN on a balcony at 9 o’clock and wa to him while slightly raising his rife. The boy waves back.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) I've got eyes on a young man on a balcony, at your 9 o’clock. Keep an eye on him.  40

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Below, Eldridge raises his hand “roger that” - understood and nervously scans the surrounding buildings.

dialogues.speaker: INT SEDAN
dialogues.text: James in the front seat now rips apart the door, rips the weather stripping to just bare metal.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into mic) It’s not in the front seat... It’s not in the door...not in the floors...not in the glovebox.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) If you haven’t found it yet it’s probably under the car somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) None of the cord goes under. It’s up here -- somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: Sanborn keeps moving to avoid being a static target. Not liking this.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Eldridge now notices the MAN on a roof-top his 12 o'clock holding the video camera.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) You got eyes on a guy with a video camera?  4l SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) No. Where?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) He’s right at my 12 o’clock. You see him? He’s pointing the thing right at me!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Jabbing his knife into the upholstery.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Negative. I don’t see him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Eldridge raises his rifle, motions for the man to leave. The man ignores him, keeps filming. Eldridge flips.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Right at my 12 - look 12 o'clock!

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: Sanborn jogs over to the side of the roof where he can no see the MAN that Eldridge is referring to.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Roger that, I got him. Yeah, he’s shady.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Eldridge lifting his gun.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) So what’s the play?  42 SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) Be smart. Make a good decision. Off Eldridge’s panic:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Ripping wires in the car, increasingly frustrated, sotto voice “more wires going nowhere.” SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) Hey James, how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into mic) I’m wonderful. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: More and more, FACES are appearing in the windows around Sanborn and Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) We’ve been here a while. We need to get out of here soon. We got a lot of eyes on us.

dialogues.speaker: INT SEDAN
dialogues.text: James ignores this. He’s in a flow state, the athlete tot focused on the game. He retraces what’s left of the wire yet again. Thinking. SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) We got to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) Roger that. I’m going to figure this out.  43 SANBORN O.S. James, we need to get out of here. James ignores him. SANBORN O.S. James do you copy? James throws his headset walkie talkie out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It lands with a rattle on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) I’m a sitting duck.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: Sanborn sees below a SOLDIER helping an older woman out o the building. The soldier looks up to Sanborn and gives h thumbs up sign.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: How’s it looking down there?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: All clear.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) The building is evacuated. We can leave, let the engineers handle this mess.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Are we moving?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) That’s affirmative.  44

dialogues.speaker: SEDAN
dialogues.text: James pulls out the car radio. Suddenly -- The car’s rain wipers SCREECH and flap across the windshi

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What’s going on with James. He's not answering me.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I think he removed his headset.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie to Eldridge) Will you tell him to his radio back on.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (shouting to James) Hey James, Sergeant Sanborn is asking if you’ll please put your headset back on. James raises his hand and gives Eldridge the middle-finge ‘fuck-you’. ELDRIDGE (CONT’D) (into walkie to Sanborn) That’s a negative. It’s not happening.  45

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: Sanborn is pacing now, like a caged lion. He notices three MEN at a minaret behind him and waves to them.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I got eyes on three guys at the minaret. Six o’clock.

dialogues.speaker: INT SEDAN
dialogues.text: James keeps working. He gets out, checks under the hood o the car. Traces the wires there.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What the hell is he doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know - it looks like he’s checking the oil.

dialogues.speaker: SEDAN
dialogues.text: James pulls a wire. The windshield wipers stop their horr screeching. He goes back inside the car, checking under the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: The angry MAN in the minaret that didn’t wave is now join by two other MEN, and they begin to point to Sanborn, and then down to James and Eldridge. They wave to the VIDEO CAMERA MAN. He waves back to them.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) They’re communicating with your camera man.  46

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) This is bad. SANBORN O.S. (into walkie) Get behind a Jersey barrier.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (into walkie) I can’t keep eyes on James from here. Eldridge stands. SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) Get down. Now. Eldridge crouches back down. Not sure what’s right or wro anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (to James) We can go!

dialogues.speaker: INT SEDAN
dialogues.text: James ignores Eldridge and continues to work. Finally, he finds what he’s looking for under a tangle of wires: a bl box. Slowly prying off the lid, taking it apart. Then he throws the black box. It goes flying out of the c James gets out. Shouts to Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We're done... Sanborn, let’s get out of here! He picks up his headset, waves to Sanborn to come down of the roof.  47

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING ROOF
dialogues.text: Sanborn bangs open the door to the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UN BUILDING PARKING LOT MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: James is flushed, red, sweat dripping as he approaches th Humvee, a big satisfied grin on his face. Sanborn, furious, charges him.

dialogues.speaker: INT UN BUILDING HUMVEE MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: James gets inside the vehicle, lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That was good. Sanborn leans into the window.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Hey, James.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah? Sanborn JABS him in the jaw, knocking the cigarette out.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Never turn your headset off again. Sanborn stalks off and James explodes out of the car. He crouches down, searching the floor of the Humvee. Sees cigarette, cleans it off, then goes back to his smoke. Once again, calm as can be, looking at Sanborn, consideri him. As James puffs away, watching Sanborn, two HUMVEE’s drive down the ramp to the parking area of the building. Several soldiers exit, among them is COLONEL REED. SOLDIE trot along beside him. The Colonel strides up to Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: You the guy in the bomb suit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sir. That's Sergeant James. He’s right here. (to James) Somebody here to see you. James comes around.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hello, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: (to James, pointing) You the guy in the flaming car? Sergeant James?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: Well, that’s just hot shit. You’re a wild man, you know that? The Colonel spins his head around to an aide.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: He’s a wild man, you know that? (back to James) Let me shake your hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: How many bombs have you disarmed, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m not quite sure.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: Sergeant, I asked you a question.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: One hundred and seventy three. Counting today, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: One hundred and seventy three? That must be a record. So tell me, what’s the best way to go about disarming one of these things? 48  49

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: The way you don’t die.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL REED
dialogues.text: Good one. Spoken like a wild man. That’s good.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT CAMP VICTORY FIRST SERGEANT’S TRAILER AFTERNOON James, sitting on a bench under a camo net, grabs a smoke inspects a circuit board. A soccer ball rolls beside him. James picks it up. The DVD kid, Beckham, comes up to retr the ball.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Give it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Look who it is. I want my five bucks back, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Five dollars - for what? Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Those DVDs you sold me were crap.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: No, you're crazy. That’s impossible. It’s Hollywood special effects.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It was shaky and out of focus, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Special effects! What do you want, donkey porn? Girls on dog? Just tell me what you want! Are you gay? You want gay sex? The boy’s chutzpa amuses James. He’s starting to like thi kid.  50

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What’s your name anyway?

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Beckham.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh yeah - like the soccer player? You good like him, too?

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Better, my man. James gets up. Motions for the kid to give him space.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Alright, make you a deal. If you can stop the ball I’1l give you five bucks --

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: -- Five dollars? More like ten, twenty.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: But if you can’t, I’m going keep the ball. Deal?

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Deal. The boy runs to a makeshift goal post. James prepares to

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Ready? One, two -- He kicks the ball in Beckham’s direction and it flies up Beckham blocks it easily. He’s very skillful.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: -- three. Shit. Beckham comes back over to James, ball in hand, and notic the bomb patch on James’ uniform.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: (pointing to the patch) Come on, where’s the five dollars. You are EOD. EOD -- boomala boomala. It’s fun, no? It’s gangsta? James is surprised by the question. Not sure how to reply  51

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah I think so. Tell you what, kid, I’'1l buy another DVD but if it’s shaky or out of focus or in any way not 100 percent, I’m going to chop off your head with a dull knife. (long beat) I'm kidding. James affectionately puts the kid in a headlock.

dialogues.speaker: INT CAMP VICTORY GARAGE
dialogues.text: Eldridge is repairing something near the under carriage o the HUMVEE when the psychiatrist approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: How’s it going?

dialogues.speaker: EDLDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Good. Breaks are squeaky.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Good. Sleep is good. Eating well. Feeling pretty squared away.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Glad to hear it. You getting along with the men in your unit?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, my team is great. My team leader is inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: You being sarcastic, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: No. I mean, he’s going to get me killed. I almost died yesterday. But at least I’1l die in the line of duty, ‘Proud and Strong.’

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: You know, this doesn’t have to be a bad time in your life. Going to war is_a_ once in a life time experience. It can be fun.  52

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: And you know this from your extensive work in the field?

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: I’ve done my field duty.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Where was that - Yale?

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Look, if you want to stop talking to me, you can. These sessions are voluntary. Eldridge considers this.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I appreciate what you’re saying. But you need to get out from behind the wire. See what we do.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: If the circumstance calls for it, I will. Just like any other soldier.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD PURGATORY DAY
dialogues.text: We're at the south end of an EXPLOSIVES DISPOSAL RANGE, nicknamed, ‘Purgatory’ -- an empty expanse of dirt pockma with craters.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER
dialogues.text: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 17

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: A tremendous EXPLOSION, by far the largest we’ve seen yet kicks out a mushroom cloud of debris. We move across the field with the cloud and settle where EOD team is positioned by their Humvee. Sanborn has a remote detonator in his hand and is about t trigger it a second time.  53

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Ready for second det? Fire in the hole. Fire in the hole. James cheerfully interrupts --

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. I think I forgot my gloves back there. James jumps into the Humvee and drives down range, revers the course we just took. It’s a long way to the explosives, at least half a mile. Sanborn and Eldridge watch him recede in the distance. James is a tiny figure ambling around the explosives pile Sanborn looks down at the detonator in his hand. Eldridge notices the look.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (re detonator) Those detonators misfire all the time.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, shit happens. They misfire.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: He’d be obliterated to nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: His helmet would be left, you could have that. Little specs of hair charred on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, there would be half a helmet somewhere...specs of hair.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: We'd have to ask for change in technique and protocol - make sure this type of accident never happens again. You’d have to write the report.  54

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I can’t write it.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: No, are you serious about killing him? Sanborn stares at Eldridge. Dead serious. They look downrange at the their leader/tormentor. He’s recovered his gloves. He’s celebrating that fact by pumping his fists in the air.

dialogues.speaker: INT/ EXT HUMVEE DAY
dialogues.text: Find the Humvee driving across the desert void. Driving a driving. Outside, horizon of sand and sun. Inside, shell-shocked men.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE DAY
dialogues.text: The Humvee crests a hill and comes in range of a HEAVILY ARMED MAN/face wrapped in a KEFFYIEH/nationality unclear, is waving an AK-47. Behind him are four additional ARMED MEN of uncertain nationality, as well as a large, disabled SUV.

dialogues.speaker: INT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: In the turret, Eldridge fingers the trigger of his .50 machine gun.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE SANBORN
dialogues.text: (shouting below) Roger that. 12 o'clock. I see an SUV. I got four armed men. They’re in Haji gear.  55

dialogues.speaker: JAMES SANBORN
dialogues.text: Careful now, guys. (to James) We're in it now.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Eldridge, stay on that fifty.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: The keffiyeh-clad man stops waving his arms, and walks towards the HUMVEE. Sanborn brakes. James and Sanborn charge out of the vehicle, blood boilin guns high, yelling: DROP YOUR FUCKING GUNS! HANDS UP! ON

dialogues.speaker: KNEES
dialogues.text: The keffiyeh man does not comply. Instead, he shouts a re that is drowned out by the desert wind.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Hands high!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Eldridge, cover!

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I got you! Sanborn continues shouting orders: GET DOWN NOW! ON YOUR

dialogues.speaker: KNEES MOTHERFUCKER
dialogues.text: Finally, the keffiyeh man nods to his men, who lower thei prodigious weapons. Then he takes his own piece...and carefully unsnaps it fr the shoulder sling. He kneels and interlaces his hands on his head. As James and Eldridge provide cover, Sanborn rushes forwa shaking with adrenaline, M4 darting back and forth. When he’s close, Sanborn notices a pistol still strapped the man’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Pistol - take it off now.  56

dialogues.speaker: KEFFIYEH MAN
dialogues.text: (in English) What do you want me to do, put my hands up or take off my pistol?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Keep your hands up.

dialogues.speaker: KEFFIYEH MAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Sanborn reaches for his pistol. It catches in the holster then comes free.

dialogues.speaker: KEFFIYEH MAN
dialogues.text: Can I touch my fucking head now?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Slowly. Slowly unfurling his Keffiyeh... Until we see that he’s not at all Arabic but just a darkl tanned, bearded Anglo-Saxon: a former member of the Briti SAS turned MERCENARY TEAM LEADER -- who at this moment is feeling pretty sick of American yahoos.

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: We're on the same side. You guys are wired tight - you know that?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here? This is no place for a picnic.

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: We've got a flat tire. Can you help us?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Sure. Do you have spares?

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: We have a spare but we used up our wrench.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: How do you use up a wrench?

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: (pointing to FEISAL, one of the mercenaries) That guy - he threw it at someone.  57

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (to FEISAL) You know you don’t have to throw wrenches. You can shoot people here.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Fuck off. They walk back to the contractor’s vehicle, where two ENE PRISONERS OF WAR (EPWs, or so we assume), shrouded in bla hoods, hands bound, are kneeling uncomfortably on the des floor.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROAD MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: A moment of calm: FEISAL crouches by the SUV’s flat tire, twisting a wrench A second mercenary - call him JIMMY - gives a drink of wa to the two bound and hooded EPWs. The two remaining mercenaries, CHRIS and CHARLIE, quietly stand guard around the perimeter of the SUV. Sanborn relieves his bladder on an innocent sand dune. James and Eldridge are hanging out with the MERCENARY TEA LEADER. He’s bragging about his two high-value prisoners, appear in a DECK of MOST WANTED PLAYING CARDS.

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: (re: the EPW’s) Picked them up in Najaf. Nine of hearts... Jack of Clubs.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Same guys?

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: That’s them. James, mildly impressed, notices that Feisal is having an issue with the tire wrench.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: Need a little help there? What’s the problem with the tire? Why the delay?  58

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: No good, boss. This wrench is too small.

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: Alright, solutions anyone?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I think there is another wrench in the back of the Humvee if you want to check.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Thanks, I’11 look. Feisal walks to the EOD HUMVEE.

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: How long are you guys out here?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Specialist, what do we got?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: We've got...ah...seventeen more days.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: But no one is counting, right. Feisal returns with a new wrench, when...

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: Contact left! Contact left!

dialogues.speaker: CONTRACTORS.
dialogues.text: Bedlam: as the firing continues on all sides, the mercena scramble for supplies and ammunition in their SUV, follow the commands of their leader who shouts “Jimmy get the go bags,” “Charlie, grab the Barrett”, “Chris take the fifty “into the ravine”, etc.  59 CHRIS leaps into the HUMVEE turret and sprays bullets in directions. The soldiers dash for cover into

dialogues.speaker: EXT RAVINE
dialogues.text: a nearby ravine, and continue firing indiscriminately

dialogues.speaker: HUMVEE
dialogues.text: Chris makes the big gun smoke. Spent brass spins red hot out of the barrel and large cal bullets pound the desert. But there is no enemy in sight.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (shouting) What are we shooting at?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (shouting back) I don’t know! suv In the confusion, the two hooded prisoners rise up and ru blindly into the desert.

dialogues.speaker: RAVINE
dialogues.text: Seeing that his valuable prisoners are escaping, the TEAM LEADER shouts:

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: The packages are moving!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: They will not get far on foot.  60

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: Three bloody months hunting those fuckers. I’m out five hundred thousand quid! With that, the TEAM LEADER brazenly dashes into the open order to get an angle on the fleeing prisoners and as bul snap around him he shoots the prisoners in the back. Then he bolts to the ravine, very pleased with himself: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER (CONT’D) I forgot, it’s five hundred thousand DEAD OR ALIVE!

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROAD
dialogues.text: Chris in the turret of the Humvee keeps firing the machin gun in all directions.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT DEEP RAVINE
dialogues.text: As the shooting continues, the Mercenary Team Leader scrambles up one side of the ravine.

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: Jimmy, give me the Barrett. [referring to a .50 caliber tripod-mounted sniper rifle] The Mercenary Team Leader hoists this heavy gun to the ed of the ravine and looks down the scope. Jimmy crawls next to him with a spotting scope in hand.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROAD
dialogues.text: Chris is still working the machine gun, expending hundred bullets a minute.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT DEEP RAVINE
dialogues.text: The Mercenary Leader says to Jimmy:

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: Chris is shooting wild. We have to conserve ammo.  61

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (into radio) Hey Chris - can you hear me? Chill out on the fifty.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROAD
dialogues.text: Chris ceases fire for a moment and takes his finger off t trigger. Silence while he keys his walkie.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Roger that. -- A bullet strikes him in the neck, killing him instantl

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: He shot Chris. The mercenary team leader deflates. He rests his chin on rifle. Everyone else in the ravine ceases firing as the futility their situation sinks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scanning the barren landscape. Gravel and sun. No enemy, a living soul in sight. Then...a structure...a one-story building, in the far distance.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It must be coming from that building.

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: I can’t see anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heat shimmers.  62 Then...on the roof of the building...slight movement. Possibly, it’s a MAN lying prone. Possibly, it’s two MEN.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Movement on the roof. The mercenary team leader concentrates his aim. He fires.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING
dialogues.text: A pause while the bullet closes the gap - then SMASHES in the building’s side, tearing apart bricks and mortar. The figures on the roof, if they are men, have certainly unharmed.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Three meters higher.

dialogues.speaker: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: I’ve got to adjust. He jostles the heavy sniper rifle forward a few inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the building, an INSURGENT SNIPER team peers at th ridge-ravine complex where the mercenaries and soldiers h taken cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wispy form of the two mercenaries lying on the ridge be faintly seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sniper’s muzzle FLASHES.  63

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE
dialogues.text: The mercenary team leader hoists himself up into a low cr only to -- --take the bullet square in the chest --spinning him off the ridge -- face first into the ravine -- his back a pulped and bloody mess from the exit wound.

dialogues.speaker: RAVINE
dialogues.text: Jimmy jumps down from the ridge to check for a pulse.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: He’s dead. Now the men plummet into a full-bore panic and everyone starts talking at once.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN JAMES
dialogues.text: I’ll get on the Barret. Go, go.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE JAMES
dialogues.text: No Sanborn don’t do that. Go, go. Stay low.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER CONTRACTOR DISPATCH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (into radio) ) Roger that, Alpha Nine. Go This is Alpha Nine. We’re in ahead. deep shit. We’re taking incoming fire.

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE
dialogues.text: Sanborn crawls to the Barrett, followed by James, who tak Jimmy's spotting scope. Effectively, our soldiers have replaced the first sniping team.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (into walkie) We are taking incoming fire. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 JIMMY (cont'd) I have two KIA. Correction three KIA. Can you get us some help?

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Roger that Alpha Nine. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER CONTRACTOR
dialogues.text: Our grid -- MDRF:5542973420. DISPATCH O.S. Alpha Nine, this is Big North Seven. You are going to have to sit tight. Off his despair:

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE
dialogues.text: Sanborn prepares to shoot at the men in the building.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (quietly) Breathe easy. I got movement at that house. 800 meters. By the window: you have a target

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Got it. Sanborn squeezes the trigger. The muzzle flashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bullet strikes the left side of the house. Another miss

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (softly) A little left. Sanborn squeezes the trigger... only to hear the METALLIC CLICK of an empty chamber.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I’m out of ammo.  65

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I’m out of ammo.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (shouting over his shoulder) Eldridge! We need ammo.

dialogues.speaker: RAVINE
dialogues.text: Eldridge frantically searches a few nearby backpacks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I need that ammo man!

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I'm looking. Where is it? JAMES O.S. Check the dead guy. Eldridge flips over the body of the slain contractor. His chest is pulped. Nestled in the gore are several .50 magazines. Eldridge g them with shaky hands and passes them up to James.

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE
dialogues.text: James passes the ammo to Sanborn. He slams it into the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Same target.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Got it. Sanborn pulls the trigger. Click. ECU: Hand cycling the weapon. Finger pulling trigger. Bol catching, jammed.  66

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: It’s jammed. The blood is making it jam. Sanborn removes the clip and hands it back to James who h it back down to Eldridge in the ravine, instructing him:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Eldridge, you got to clean the blood off the bullets. The blood is making it jam. Eldridge takes the magazine and rubs the top bullet to no good effect, for the dust on his hands sticks to the bloo and the blood sticks to the bullet. He rubs harder, only making it dirtier. James peers down and realizes that Eldridge is lost.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Spit and rub, man. Spit on them. Eldridge tries to spit on the bullets. His mouth is too dry to produce salvia. He tries again. Nothing. James sees his escalating despair and slides down the rid coming next to Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Use your camel (referring to the Camelback water canteen). James squeezes the nipple of Eldridge’s Camel and directs water to drip on the bullets. It sort of works. Sitting side by side now, they rub away the grime and pol the bullets to a bright shine.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You're doing good, man. You’re okay. I’m going to keep you safe. James takes the clean bullets and climbs back to the ridg telling Eldridge:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Scan your sectors.  67

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE
dialogues.text: Sanborn loads the clean bullets and fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One figure on the roof is hit. The other man crawls back out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Nice. You got him. Second one is out of range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scanning... Another FIGURE, lying on the desert floor.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Twenty meters to the right of the building. You got a target.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I got him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Fire when ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanborn’s bullet strikes the ground a dozen feet in front the man, kicking up a harmless puff of dust. The man gets up and runs towards the building while firin his AK-47 back at Sanborn and James. His carbine’s muzzle flash, ineffective at this great range, sparkles in the bright day.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He’s moving to the building. Follow him. You got him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got him. Sanborn pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 Sanborn’s bullet strikes the fleeing man in the upper che blood spurting as the large round throws him dead to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You got him. He’s down. Good night. Thanks for playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sniper in the building appears in the window.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING
dialogues.text: The insurgent sniper team leans out the window and fires James and Sanborn.

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE
dialogues.text: The bullet snaps near James and Sanborn.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Window! Window!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Got it. Sanborn fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at Miss! Sanborn’s bullet strikes the building just below th window and the insurgent team withdraws inside.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He’s still there.  69 The insurgent, having run to the other side of the buildi now appears in the other window, the left window. James s his barrel.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Left window! Left window! Got him?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Got him. Sanborn turns his head away from the gun and makes an aud exhale to release tension: the sniper breath control technique. Then he fires a hit; the insurgent slumps in t window.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He’s down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roof of the tall building in the distance bobs in and of view; the scope dances at this range. James scans the area. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
