dialogues.text: We mark the passage of time with dust devils spinning acr a horizon of lengthening shadows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT DEEP RAVINE HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: The sun lower in the sky. Around the pit, the fallen TEAM LEADER has been pushed to one side, and the living are hanging on to their sanity. Eldridge and the remaining contractors have exhausted the water supply. Eldridge is in a sentry position facing east, in the direction of the railroad tracks. The other two contracto are in sentry positions facing south and north. Sanborn and James are in EXACTLY the same position as whe left them, exposed to the elements. Desert heat and sand taken their toll on Sanborn especially.  70

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scope BLURS as Sanborn’s vision fails for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE
dialogues.text: James notices Sanborn’s fatigue.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Eldridge, grab me the juice out of an MRE. Eldridge digs around the dead TEAM LEADER'S backpack and retrieves a packet of juice, which he passes to James. James inserts the straw into the juice pack. He hesitates, not sure if Sanborn will accept the gesture after all the hostility that’s passed between them... James brings the straw to Sanborn’s lips. At first, Sanborn keeps his attention on the rifle scope.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Drink. with some discomfort, Sanborn opens his sun-scorched lips sips.

dialogues.speaker: RAVINE
dialogues.text: Eldridge scans the horizon-- --a small HERD of GOATS amble along the railroad tracks. He rubs his eyes, looks again-- --Somewhere within the herd a flutter of fabric-- Eldridge stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Uh, Will.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah.  71

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: At your six o'clock. Movement on the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Uh, okay. Eldridge looks down his scope, unsure. James keeps his fo forward on the building.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Should I fire?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Your call. Eldridge shifts his weight onto his rifle. Another flutter of movement at the edge of the tracks. Eldridge pulls the trigger. Then he pulls it again. And again, emptying his magazine at the distant target. The goats scatter, revealing a lifeless BODY draped acros the tracks. Eldridge slumps, let’s go of his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: RAVINE SEVERAL HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Dusk. Shadows fall over James and Sanborn, both of whom remain lying in the exact same sniping position, although they are covered head to toe in sand. There’s no movement in the house. No movement on the far ridge. No sign of life anywhere beyond their encampment. It’s just them and the sky and the desert.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I think we're done.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 72 INT CAMP VICTORY JAMES’ TRAILER NIGHT Play time: James and Sanborn square off, drunk, swaying, faced, fists clenched. When Sanborn nods, James punches h in the stomach. James smiles; he looks good. The unleashed aggression is a vitamin to him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s what you get for hitting your team-leader, motherfucker. With difficulty, Sanborn straightens up and stumbles out the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Be right back. I gotta piss. James lurches towards Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Owen, another round. That’s an order.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (imitating a young recruit) Yes, Sir, Sergeant James Sir. You're not very good with people are you -- but you’re a natural warrior.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You acquitted yourself well on the field of battle today, Specialist. They clink cups. Eldridge gulps his whiskey. James collapses in his chair. Eldridge sits down carefully.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I was scared.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Everyone is a coward about something. (beat) You did good.  73 As Sanborn loudly stumbles back into the room, he notices the door something a little odd under James’ bed: a box. odd because there is nothing else in the barren room besi Army-issue furniture, lights, and the whiskey they’ve bee drinking. Curious, Sanborn retrieves the box out and sets it ona makeshift coffee table to get a better look.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Just what do we have here? Will has possessions! I didn’t know you owned anything, Will.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Let’s see what you got. Sanborn pulls out a weathered snapshot of a baby boy.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s my son. He’s a real tough little bastard. Nothing like me.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: You’re married?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Well, I had a girlfriend. She got pregnant and we got married and then we divorced. Or, I thought we divorced. She’s still in the house and she says we're still together. So I don’t know. What does that make her?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Dumb - for still being with your ass.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (hotly) She ain’t dumb. She’s just loyal, that’s all. (beat) What about you guys - what have you got?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: My problem is the girl I like I can’t stop from talking about babies.  74

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Give her your sperm, stud. Make babies!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Go on, you chickenshit. Do it!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No, I know when I’m ready and I’m not ready for that yet. (looking around the box, finds a circuit board) And what do we have here?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Components. Bomb parts. Signatures.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I see that. But what are they doing under your bed? James pulls out a circuit and gazes reverently at the mechanical design.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: This one is from the UN building, flaming car. Dead man switch - boom! This guy was good. I like him. This one was from our first call together. This box is full of stuff that almost killed me. Eldridge rummages through the box and finds a gold ring hanging from a cheap chain. He dangles the ring in front of James.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: What’s this one from, Will?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That’s my wedding ring. Like I said, stuff that almost killed me. (beat) I think it’s interesting to hold something in your hands that could have killed any one of us.  75

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (looking at the circuit board) It’s a piece of junk from Radio Shack. Eldridge, ever unsure, allies with James.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: It’s interesting.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES SANBORN
dialogues.text: I agree. I think it’s I think that punch was harder interesting, too. than I hit you. Therefore, I owe you a punch. So get up motherfucker. James leaps up, pleased to end the conversation. Sanborn follows, clapping his hands -- cruising for a bruising.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Hold on, we need some rules. No face shots.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (laughing) There’s gonna be a face shot. Eldridge picks up a magic marker and tells James to take his shirt. Then he draws a bulls-eye on James’ bared stomach. And as he does, he notices knotty scar tissue.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: My mother dropped me at birth.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE SANBORN
dialogues.text: Looks like frag scars. Let it go, Eldridge. James smiles, raises his arms, exposing his midsection to Sanborn. Sanborn winds up for a powerful blow. He leans back, then launches a gut punch that knocks James to the floor. James lies there in a heap, laughing.  76 When he gets up, he’s laughing so hard that gleeful tears down his face.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: You like that?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That all you got? Now Sanborn raises his arms, bracing for the blow. James feints a right cross, fakes a jab, then grabs Sanbo by the neck and unleashes a brutal uppercut to the solar plexus. Sanborn collapses, moaning in pain.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (laughing) That’s got to hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Get up, bitch. James extends his hand to help Sanborn off the floor. But when Sanborn reaches for help, James rushes him wildl like a football tackle, knocking him back to the floor, a in a sudden fit of aggression, he then jumps on Sanborn’s chest, pins his arms with his knees and clasps his throat

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What have you got now?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Get off me!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Come on, what have you got.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Get off of me you freak!! Sanborn tries to buck James off but he can’t dislodge the former Ranger. Sanborn redoubles his efforts, throwing his weight this w and that. Still, James remains on top -- his face twisted with a macho snarl.  77

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We got a wild one here!! Sanborn bucks harder. But instead of knocking James loose his kicking and struggling to get free spurs James to eve deeper levels of male weirdness. And as Sanborn kicks and bucks underneath him, James pumps his hand like a cowboy rodeo, crying out:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I'm riding him! That's right!! He's a wild one and I’m riding him!!

dialogues.speaker: COME ON BITCH
dialogues.text: Now Sanborn reaches for his boot knife. ECU: knife blade snapping open Sanborn jams the blade against James’ throat and their ey lock. James smiles like a child. He pats Sanborn’s head and lau

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m just kidding motherfucker!! Shit!!! At last, Sanborn is released. James pats him on the chest

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You're alright, Sanborn. (to Eldridge) Owen, get this guy another drink.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Sanborn, too drunk to stand, is being guided across the barracks square by Eldridge and James. When they come to Eldridge’s trailer, James shoulders Sanborn by himself an Eldridge goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Later. It’s not easy for James to carry Sanborn alone and Sanbor nearly slips to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You need to go on a diet.  78 They walk a little farther to Sanborn’s trailer, passing SOLDIER who looks at them curiously. Drinking is not allo on US bases in Iraq. James brushes aside the officious lo saying “he hurt his knee” and guides Sanborn up a set of stairs into Sanborn’s trailer. INT. SANBORN’S TRAILER James eases Sanborn onto a cot and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Get some rest. Sanborn mumbles drunkenly:

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Hey James, do you think I have what it takes to put on the suit?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (beat) Hell no. (Beat) Good night, boy. INT JAMES’ TRAILER LATER THAT NIGHT James stumbles inside, flops on the bed, and takes anothe swig of whiskey. He lies there and stares at his bomb helmet, which is sit on a desk adjacent to his cot. He looks at the helmet... and reaches for it. Then he brings the helmet over his head and adjusts the straps and unlocks the glass protective masks, so that it snaps down over his face and his entire head is sheathed the protective metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man encased in his armor. He leans back in the bed and we HEAR the rasp of James BREATHING. ..daydreaming...as he re-experiences the feeli a bomb in his hands, the morbid thrill.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT HUMVEE CAMP VICTORY PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: A massive sandstorm is underway. Howling winds disperse r sand over the entire base, giving it an otherworldly, alm Martian aspect. Throngs of men and their vehicles fight t brutal weather.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Days Left in Bravo Company’s Rotation: 16 Lt. Col. Cambridge comes out of the gloom, approaches the vehicles window, and knocks.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Mind if I ride along? I’m sick of sitting behind a desk all the time. James shoots Eldridge a look. Eldridge shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It’s a privilege. (as Cambridge gets in) ) I don’t mean to insult your intelligence, Sir, but if the shit hits the fan please don’t fire out the Humvee, the rounds will just bounce around and someone might get shot. I don’t like getting shot.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Understood, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ABU GHRAIB CENTER BOMBED OUT BUILDING DAY
dialogues.text: A partially destroyed building fills the screen. A mess o bricks and rebar. Wind swirls sand up into the air.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 16 Nearby, an OLD IRAQI MAN with a DONKEY drawn cart is unloading new bricks to repair the building. Farther up the road, a good distance from the building, a two parked Humvees. Nearby, James and his team are talkin a small cluster of SOLDIERS. Eldridge gives Cambridge the drill:  80

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: This is a pretty standard mission. We're just here to pick up some ordnance. Sergeant James is going to go see what the deal is. Hopefully, we’re gone in a couple of minutes

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Guys, we got to gear up.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Security hasn’t gone in. Let’s just go in quiet, radios off.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Glad you came.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Stay safe.

dialogues.speaker: INT BOMBED OUT BUILDING
dialogues.text: James, Sanborn and Eldridge enter a landing. The floor is very wet. They cross it, and come to a room that has been severely damaged by a bomb, with rubble everywhere and exposed electrical wires dangling from the ceiling, and busted pipes gushing water. A tea pot sits on a STOVE, steaming hot, and a plate on the table has bread on it.

dialogues.speaker: WATER LOGGED ROOM
dialogues.text: They gingerly investigate a large cavernous room with lea pipes dripping water onto an oil-slicked floor. We HEAR t breathing, the water DROPLETS falling. Moving tactically, covering all sides of their approach, they press deeper i the building down

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: A dark corridor which the insurgents have strewn with gla as an early-warning system. Advancing slowly, glass CRUNC underfoot, they pass through this corridor into  81

dialogues.speaker: CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: A classroom lined with student’s desks and chairs, beyond which lies another room. James and Sanborn spin quietly i this room, rifles raised, while Eldridge hangs back to co the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: INSURGENT LIVING SPACE
dialogues.text: They find themselves in a recently used living area. A te cooking on a bunsen burner hisses steam. Mattresses and bedding line the walls of the room. The walls are decorat with Jihadist slogans, and a video camera for making recruiting videos has pride of place on a tripod in the center of the room. Sanborn checks under the mattresses for hidden explosives finds none, and exchanges a worried look with James. Moving as one unit they spin into the next room.

dialogues.speaker: EMPTY ROOM
dialogues.text: It’s empty, another forboding large space strewn with rub and garbage. They pass through this area and push open a to --

dialogues.speaker: BOMB FACTORY
dialogues.text: Santa’s bomb making factory. In contrast to the spare spaces they’ve just passed throu this room is overflowing with the tools of a an insurgenc that uses bombs as its primary weapon: electronics and explosives of all kinds are everywhere: artillery shells, boxes of batteries, plastic explosives, military manuals, rockets, grenades, stacks of dynamite, tools, magnifying glasses, and soldering guns. Though a few of these munitions bear the stamps of foreig militaries, most bear insignias in English. It is, ironically, a cache of armaments that formerly belonged t the American military. The men weave through the piles of explosives, slowly checking every space where a human could possibly be hidi At last they’re satisfied:  82

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Clear! Eldridge draws near to one desk where a cigarette burns i ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: This cigarette is still smoking!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: This is all our shit. Motherfucking gold mine. Watch out for trips.

dialogues.speaker: BACK OF ROOM
dialogues.text: In the back half of the room, a plastic curtain hangs ove work table, forming a make-shift sterile room. Smelling the copper odor of blood and death emanating fro behind that curtain, James pushes the plastic to one side He draws near to a table, where he sees the DEAD BODY of YOUNG BOY wearing pants but no shirt. Flies buzz over his bloody bare chest.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I got something. Sanborn and Eldridge come beside him, and approach the bo cautiously. The dead young man’s chest has been cut open. An artiller shell is shoved inside the cavity where the heart used to beat. Wires protrude from the shell. James shakes his head no as Sanborn moves closer to the b and inspects the wiring in the chest. The boy’s FACE, half in shadow, is so disfigured by bruis that it’s hard to identify. But it might be someone famil to James.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I know this kid. His name is Beckham. He sells DVDs. Sanborn ignores that and turns to Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: You ever see a body bomb before?  83 Eldridge shakes his head, pulling his neck scarf up over nose.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: This is disgusting, let’s get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Eldridge, grab all the C4 and det cord you can get your hands on. Let’s get the rest of it out of here and just blow it in place.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Roger that. Sanborn and Eldridge leave James alone with the body. He stares at the boy.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BOMBED OUT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Cambridge, with limited Iraqi language skills, is trying speak to a MAN piling rocks in the back of his donkey car

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Moving the rocks? The Iraqi peasant replies in Arabic, motioning to the roc and his cart.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: That’s very nice. It’s a little unsafe today. So maybe - I don’t know - I’m thinking maybe we should move.

dialogues.speaker: INT BODY BOMB
dialogues.text: James steps away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BOMBED OUT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Sanborn and Eldridge meet up outside.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: You okay?  84

dialogues.speaker: EDLDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You?

dialogues.speaker: INT BOMBED OUT BUILDING MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: James turns away from the body. Thinks. Eldridge arrives with the C4. The look on James’ face concerns him.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: You alright man?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah, no one in or out. Eldridge nods. Makes a hasty exit. James pulls C4 blocks from his pack and arranges them aro the body. He plugs a blasting cap into the C4. In doing s finds himself drawn to the dead boy’s eyes, which seem somehow to stare directly at him. James tries to keep his feelings in check and his mind on task by arranging the charges and preparing the detonatio But he can’t. The war has finally reached him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Cancel the det. In one fluid motion James removes the charges and takes o his helmet. He closes the boy’s eyes. And slams his fists on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanborn and Eldridge grab water by the Humvee.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What the fuck is he doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.  85

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE AT THE DONKEY CART
dialogues.text: Now there are a few IRAQI MEN gathered near the donkey ca Cambridge is doing his best to communicate.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Hello, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: IRAQI MAN
dialogues.text: Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: New York. The Big Apple.

dialogues.speaker: IRAQI MAN
dialogues.text: I’m from Iraq.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: I love it here. This is a beautiful place. But today, it’s not too safe here, so I think we need to move. Please.

dialogues.speaker: INT BOMBED OUT BUILDING
dialogues.text: James carefully checks the boy’s body for trip wires, the proceeds the snip the wires which were sown into the boy’ stomach. One by one, he cuts them. He inserts his hands into the boy’s abdomen and removes t artillery shell bomb that had been diabolically placed th He wipes his face, smearing blood, then covers the body i white cloth.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into walkie) I’m coming down. The boy’s blood seeps through the cloth and stains it red

dialogues.speaker: INT BOMBED OUT BUILDING STAIRS
dialogues.text: James carries the boy’s body down the narrow corridor. Th head and feet bump the sides.  86

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET/BOMBED OUT BUILDING
dialogues.text: James brings the body out carries it to a blue and white pickup TRUCK emblazoned with the logo of the Iraqi Nation Police pulls up to their position. A pair of POLICEMEN get out and after a few words with Ja they load the body.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BOMBED OUT BUILDING
dialogues.text: James watches the police truck drive away. He then moves the Humvee, motioning for Cambridge to load up.

dialogues.speaker: INT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: Sanborn and Eldridge sit across from each other, watching James.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: .»+-So you think it was that little base rat?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: You positive?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Sure. I don’t know. They all look the same, right?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Will seemed sure. But that was weird.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Very weird.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE AT THE DONKEY CART
dialogues.text: Cambridge, losing patience with what is now a small crowd Iraqis, motions with his M4.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Please, just move. Please. Ishmee (pronouncing the Arabic incorrectly).  87 The crowd slowly disperses, amid grumbling and cursing. Cambridge waves patronizingly at them as they go, saying “thank you, bye-bye,” etc. He doesn’t notice that one of older men has left on the ground a_white rice bag.

dialogues.speaker: INT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: Simultaneously, the conversation in the Humvee continues:

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: But then Will's pretty weird. He keeps bomb parts under his bed.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I bet you he doesn’t keep any of these parts under his bed. James cracks the door of the Humvee, leans inside, sees Cambridge -

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (shouting to Cambridge) Let's go! Through the HUMVEE windshield: Cambridge, now pleased tha the crowd has gone, waves good-bye to the entire neighborhood, and, hearing James, steps towards the Humve passing the white rice bag, which suddenly -- --explodes in a A SICKENING BLAST --obliterating Cambridge --sending his head crashing into the HUMVEE, along with a could of debris which instantly blackens the windshield a blots out the sun and our view of everything -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: CRIES of “IED!” “IED” as our three soldiers stumble out o the vehicle into the rancid air, while other soldiers, dashing to the scene from all sides, scramble to restore order and shout “it’s the commander” “watch your six”, et We follow Eldridge, stunned, as he walks into the afterma and finds a smoking helmet on the ground. He picks it up. Its nylon cover is burning; the inside is charred.  88 Eldridge looks down and sees body parts and bits of unifo strewn on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Where’s Cambridge? Cambridge! Come on, we got to go! (beat) Doc? James rushes to Eldridge’s side.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I just saw him! He was walking right here! James pulls Eldridge into a bear hug. Eldridge sobs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He’s dead. He’s dead. (beat) But you’re alright, buddy. You're alright.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY DUSK
dialogues.text: As the sun sets behind him, James leans against a power p and dials a SATELLITE PHONE. He hangs up. Dials again.

dialogues.speaker: INT SUBURBAN HOME
dialogues.text: In a modest mid-Western kitchen, the phone rings. A young WOMAN holding a BABY rushes to get it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Hello? (beat) Will? Hello? Silence on the other end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY DUSK
dialogues.text: James hangs up and shoves the phone back in his pocket.  89

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT MORNING
dialogues.text: James, smoking, twitchy, watching something... the OLDER IRAQI MAN who sells DVDs at Beckham’s usual table. Althou Beckham is not there, the man organizes his DVDs, busines usual. James stalks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hey, let me ask you a question, what happened to the little kid that used to work here? The man shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DVD MAN
dialogues.text: Sorry man, no English.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No English? Now you don’t speak English. The little kid? Beckham is his name. He sells DVDs.

dialogues.speaker: DVD MAN
dialogues.text: DVD? One DVD five dollars. James turns to a nearby INFANTRY GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Excuse me, soldier, are you in charge of this area?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That guy over there could be an insurgent. (referring to the DVD merchant) How do we know he’s not giving intel to his buddies, telling them where to drop mortars?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: I think he’s just selling DVDs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He’s a security risk. You should get rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: He’s just selling DVDs. All the merchants are cleared. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 159 90 GUARD (cont'd) I couldn't do anything to him without the say-so from my C.O. James, agitated, seeing that he has no hope of prevailing turns away and trudges back into Camp Victory’s maze.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: It’s the end of the day and the DVD seller packs up his w to close shop. James, in sunglasses, sweatshirt covering army fatigues, watches him do this, and then follows the to his truck. As the man starts the engine, James jumps i the passenger side and threatens with his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Does this change anything? Speak English now, don’t you? Drive!

dialogues.speaker: INT IRAQI TRUCK
dialogues.text: The truck passes through a middle-class Baghdad neighborh and comes to a stop at a house surrounded by an 8-foot hi concrete wall.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES 159
dialogues.text: This is the house? Beckham’s house? The driver nods, sort of.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: James gets out and jogs to the house. He tries the front gate, sees that it is locked, and while he does the car drives off. If he cares, he doesn’t show it. James scales the wall an drops inside the front courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: EXT IRAQI HOUSE COURTYARD
dialogues.text: A modest courtyard. Light comes from one window in the ho the rest is dark. Crickets. Inside, a TV is playing. Jame tries the front door. It opens.  91

dialogues.speaker: INT IRAQI HOUSE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: In a dark hallway. Murmuring of a television. James moves towards the noise.

dialogues.speaker: INT IRAQI HOUSE ANTECHAMBER
dialogues.text: James comes to an antechamber. Behind it is a very low st archway. He goes through the archway, where -

dialogues.speaker: INT IRAQI HOUSE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: A MAN -- call him KALIM -- older, fifties, dressed in Wes fashion, is busy at the sink, washing dishes. James walks gun raised. Kalim drops a dish. James puts his fingers to lips, shhhh.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Do you speak English?

dialogues.speaker: KALIM
dialogues.text: English, French, Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (quietly) Good. Open your vest. Stay there. Tell me what you know about Beckham.

dialogues.speaker: KALIM
dialogues.text: For whom?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Beckham. The 12-year old boy, the body bomb.

dialogues.speaker: KALIM
dialogues.text: Beckham? I don’t know. But please sit down. I am professor Kalim, this is my home. You are a guest. Please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m a guest...I’m just looking for the people responsible.

dialogues.speaker: KALIM
dialogues.text: You are CIA, no? I am very pleased to have CIA in my home. Please, sit.  92 As his certainty slips away, James hears rustling and spi to see -- a WOMAN, older, matronly, carrying a tea tray. She see James, his gun, and starts cursing him in Arab, appalled an armed American would come to her house. James steps back. Her cursing grows fiercer. She raises h tea tray.

dialogues.speaker: KALIM
dialogues.text: Be careful! The gun can go off. Undaunted, she throws the tray at James. He twists to avo it, takes a few steps to the door, and ends up HITTING hi HEAD badly on the concrete archway as he runs out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is shaken. He looks around and down the street. He runs...and runs...Blood runs from the wound on his head a navigates the busy Iraqi neighborhood at night, running d streets teeming with SHOPPERS who stare at him ominously, dodging traffic, moving past OLD MEN smoking at a CAFE wh note his panic, by a BUTCHER SHOP where an entire COW CAR is being unloaded, and on and on... we stay with his eyes Off the a screeching car as James dashes across a street,

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY GATE NIGHT
dialogues.text: James, hands held high over his head, walks up to one of camp's check-points, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: USA Friendly coming in! Powerful flood lights switch on, blinding him. Then the screaming of hyped up guards:

dialogues.speaker: GUARDS GUARDS
dialogues.text: Stop, get the fuck down. On Don’t fucking move! your knees!

dialogues.speaker: GUARDS GUARDS
dialogues.text: Stop! On your knees, on your knees!!  93 James sinks to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Open your fucking jacket! Cover James unzips his sweatshirt and declares:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I have a weapon! A guard armed with a shotgun charges out of the glare and kicks James to the ground, pinning his knee into his back

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Searching! The guard finds James’ pistol. He shouts:

dialogues.speaker: GUARD JAMES
dialogues.text: Like I said. (beat) Do you Gun!! Weapon’s clear!! want to look at my I.D.?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (gasping) I was at a whore house.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: (thinking it over) Okay, if I let you in, will you tell me where it is exactly?

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY NIGHT
dialogues.text: James steps into his trailer. His walkie, sitting on a de CRACKLES to life.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (over walkie) I repeat, do you copy? Do you have your ears on? James?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Yeah, this is James. What’s up?  94

dialogues.speaker: INT HUMVEE MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: In a bustling parking lot, aglow with headlights from Hum and troop carries, we find James running towards one Humv which he jumps into. Sanborn is at the wheel and not amus

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: We have a tanker explosion in the Green Zone. We have to do a post- blast assessment, see if it was a suicide bomber and if so how he pulled it off. (beat) So where did you say you were again?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I didn’t, Sergeant. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What happened to your head, James? James gives no reply. He turns to Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Ready? Game face buddy. As the Humvee rolls out of the base,

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN PRELAP
dialogues.text: USA Friendlies coming in!

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET LATE NIGHT
dialogues.text: A helicopter spotlight illuminates a Hieronymus Bosch nightmare of tangled limbs and body parts. Then fires, sm and the cries of wailing grievers and wounded carried on stretchers, ambulances, police, fire trucks...the ghastly frantic aftermath of a major detonation. Their combat flashlights send piercing white beams into t grim spectacle, while in the distance a huge fire, a GLOW RED INFERNO at the end of the block, lights what we now s is a blast radius that extends for a nearly a mile. Moving towards the glowing fire, past ten foot high flame and the remains of houses pulverized to concrete and glas rubble piles, past screaming women and more bloody wounde being carried away by IRAQI POLICE...  95 they pause to try and help Iraqi police save a man pinned under a car. He’s dragged away like a rag doll. They press on towards the inferno and stop when they noti hunk of metal.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Oil tanker?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Yup. Pretty long flight. Moving ahead, the men split up, navigating different path through this hectic apocalypse:

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: A Bhurka-clad WOMAN appears out of the distant flames and haze, looking disoriented, in apparent shock. Behind her blazing car. On the ground beside the car lies a single black loafer. Eldridge sees the lone shoe and is at a loss to process i significance. Another mind-numbing, soul-numbing casualty of war.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: At a gigantic rubble pile, Sanborn reaches down to remove chunks of stone covering a BODY. The stone slides away but another falls in its place. Sanborn looks down, sees a second man, or what’s left of man: head and torso but no legs -- just stumps, twitching Around him, GRIEVING FAMILIES pick through the dead and d with IRAQI MEDICS.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Drawing near to the inferno, he moves past burning palm t which erupt into a fountain of embers. And comes at last to the burning steel carcase of...  96

dialogues.speaker: OIL TANKER
dialogues.text: an OIL TANKER. From what's left of the twisted metal sub-frame flames tw feet high scorch the night, like the maw of hell on earth James stares, transfixed by the burning...the imprint of insurgent’s plan. His face hardens now in a way we haven’t seen before, and the fire flickers on his features he seems lost in a priv war of his own. The insurgents are out there somewhere. Ahab and the Whale.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN AND ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Sanborn and Eldridge look helplessly at a girl who is tra on the landing of a half-destroyed building. She cries fo her father. Behind them, several platoons of U.S. SOLDIERS and IRAQI POLICE arrive to secure the boundaries of the blast zone.

dialogues.speaker: EDGE OF BLAST RADIUS
dialogues.text: James approaches a LEMON GROVE which lies just beyond the fire’s reach. As Sanborn and Eldridge walk up behind him, James touches UNBLEMISHED LEMON nestled among the thorns.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: This is the edge of the blast radius. Sanborn comes into view. James nods to him, then stares i the distance, a man possessed.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: So where's our trigger man?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Burnt up in the flames. Suicide bomber. You'll never find a body.  97

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: But what if there was no body. What if it was a remote det? (beat) A really good bad guy hides out in the dark, right? This is a perfect vantage point outside the blast radius to set back and watch us --

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: You want to go out there?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I could stand to get in some trouble. Sanborn looks at James and looks at the bandage on his he

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No, man, this is bullshit. You got --what?-- three infantry platoons here whose job it is to go haji hunting. That’s not our job.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You don’t say ‘No’ to me, Sergeant. I say ‘No’ to you. You know there are guys watching us right now. (on the move) We're going. James glowers at Sanborn and Eldridge and moves deeper in an unlit field behind the lemon grove. Eldridge shoots Sanborn a sympathetic glance and follows James. Sanborn watches them recede into the darkness. Then he ru after his team.

dialogues.speaker: EXT FIELD
dialogues.text: They move across the dark field, three abreast into the enveloping night. We gradually lose sight of them in BLACKNESS. Seeing noth we HEAR, however, their BREATHING, and gravel CRUNCHING underfoot.  98 After a long moment of no visibility...they’re faintly visible again in dim florescent light and we see:

dialogues.speaker: EXT PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: A shadowy parking lot filled with marooned cars, beyond w lies a neighborhood of one-story homes and narrow alleys. Amid the cars, the men come across the bullet-shaped hull an intact oil tanker. They crouch beside it, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We know where the oil tanker came from.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: It’s the same kind.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We're close. These alleys are probably set up in a grid. We’re going to split up to flush them out. Sanborn take the first alley. Eldridge take two. I got three. Rally point at your intersection. Ready? Move!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Wait? Rally point? When? But James has already dashed into the third alley.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY TWO
dialogues.text: Eldridge, walking slowly, not sure he likes being alone.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY THREE
dialogues.text: James runs confidently, sees a few kids in a doorway and tells them to scoot.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY ONE
dialogues.text: Sanborn runs to make up for being the last to leave.  99

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY TWO
dialogues.text: Eldridge peers into an abandoned house. He thinks he hear something. Spins. It’s nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY ONE
dialogues.text: Sanborn slows. Catches his breath when suddenly -- --BLAM, BLAM, BLAM - the staccato of GUNFIRE slaps off th concrete-- Sanborn dashes full speed back to the alley’s opening.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY THREE
dialogues.text: James turns, runs hard back into--

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN AND JAMES
dialogues.text: --the first intersection, where he sees Sanborn and shout

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You got contact?!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Who is it?! What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What have you got?!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: It's Eldridge!!

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY TWO
dialogues.text: They come to Eldridge’s alley where they see that a body on the ground. They run to it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Man down!!

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Eldridge!!  100 As they draw close they see not Eldridge but the BODY of Iraqi insurgent, dead from gunshot wounds.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It’s not him.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: He’s gone?! A moment of decision.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: That way is towards the tanker, troops. They run down the alley into a maze of narrow streets and dimly lit corridors.

dialogues.speaker: NARROW STREET
dialogues.text: Turning a corner, they catch a fleeting glimpse of Eldrid being dragged away by TWO INSURGENTS. Before they can fire, the men are gone.

dialogues.speaker: CORNER
dialogues.text: They run to this corner and prepare to spin around it and shoot. James hands Sanborn his flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hit ‘em with both lights. One, two, three!

dialogues.speaker: DARK CORNER
dialogues.text: They spin around the corner and flash light revealing NOT but an empty street.

dialogues.speaker: NEXT ALLEY
dialogues.text: They sprint to the next block, and again see Eldridge bei dragged.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: One, two, three.  101 Again, they aim and spin: Sanborn shines the light - beam Eldridge and the two insurgents -- and James FIRES two sh bursts from his M4. The two insurgents collapse. But Eldridge also goes down. Running up, James and Sanborn see the insurgents are motionless, shot clean. One bullet, however, has gone astray into Eldridge’s leg he’s bleeding profusely.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Eldridge you okay?

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: I’m hit! As James and Sanborn apply first aide:

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: You hit him in the leg!

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (panting) Am I dead?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No, you're alright.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You're fine. Eldridge looks to Sanborn for confirmation that wound is indeed not mortal.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Am I dead? Am I dead? Am I dead? As Sanborn and James yank Eldridge off the ground, he scr in pain.

dialogues.speaker: INT CAMP VICTORY SHOWER STALLS LATER THAT NIGHT
dialogues.text: James trudges into an empty bathroom and looks at himself the mirror. Sees the faraway expression of a man lost to war.  102 His shirt is crimson with Eldridge’s blood. He steps inside a shower stall, still dressed in full bat rattle, and turns on the hot faucet. The water streams over him...and he lets go, punching the wall, thrashing his arms, then sinking down sobbing, brok as his uniform soaks through and the reddish pink water swirls down the drain.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY HEAD SHED MORNING
dialogues.text: Looking fine and wearing a fresh clean uniform, James str purposely out of the head shed toward a waiting Humvee in parking lot. He sees on the other side of the parking lot... none othe than Beckham, who happily shouts to him:

dialogues.speaker: BECKHAM
dialogues.text: Hey, what’s up man? Hey Boomala, Boomala, wanna buys some DVDs, play some soccer! James stops. He stares. What can he say? The boy is fine. His jihad was pointless. Insane. Unable to face the kid and unwilling to explain, James tu away and stiffly gets into the Humvee. The Humvee roars to life and drives away. Beckham watches it go, hurt, confused. Prelap: the ROTAR WASH of a helicopter preparing to fly.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CAMP VICTORY TARMAC MORNING
dialogues.text: Two SOLDIERS load Eldridge, strapped to a stretcher, onto transport helicopter. Sanborn and James run across the helipad to wish him good bye.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: How you doing? Doc says you’ll be okay.  103

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: My femur is shattered in nine places. He said I'll be walking in six months if, I’m lucky.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Six ain’t bad.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: Not bad? It fucking sucks man. Eldridge is jostled as he gets put down; he cries out in pain.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (angrily) You see that! That’s what happens when you shoot somebody, you motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: You're sorry? Fuck you, Will. Really fuck you. Thanks for saving my life but we didn’t have to go out looking for trouble so you could get your adrenaline fix, you fucking war mongerer. James is crestfallen. A U.S. MEDIVAC CREW MEMBER looks at Sanborn and gives a h signal to wrap it up: time to go.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: (to Sanborn) Take care of yourself, Owen.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (grabbing Eldridge’s hand) Get home safe. See you on the other side. As the helicopter door slams closed, Eldridge shouts “let get out of this desert.” James and Sanborn step back from the rotor wash. James turns to say something to Sanborn. But he’s already walking away.  104

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER PRELAP
dialogues.text: (shouting) Don’t move! If you keep walking, we will shoot you!

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD STREET CHECKPOINT LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A young SERGEANT at a checkpoint raises his M4 and shouts nervously at a bewildered Iragi MAN in a BLACK SUIT. The man’s hands are raised. He’s standing alone in the middle a square which has been cleared of all other pedestrians, which is flanked by US ARMY soldiers and a TRANSLATOR disguising his identity by wearing a black ski mask.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Don’t move! Keep that translator back!

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: But the bomb was forced on him.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Don’t move. Stay still. If you keep walking we will shoot you. SHOUTING IN ARABIC as the translator conveys this command

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 2 James wearing his bomb suit, approaches the scene, while Sanborn follows close behind him in the Humvee.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Keep that translator back. One of the soldiers grabs the translator, while others, seeing James, shout “give him room,” “let him through,” e

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: (to the soldier) But the bomb was forced on him. Against his will. He is not a bad man! James and the Sergeant huddle.  105

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: He came walking up to our checkpoint, said he had a bomb strapped to him. He was sorry. He didn’t want it to go off. Then he started begging us to take it off him.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: (to James) Help this man. He’s not a bad man.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Not a bad man? He’s got a bomb strapped to him. (to James) This is a trap. He wants to draw us close.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to translator) Tell him to open his shirt, slowly. I need to see what’s inside. The translator SHOUTS in Arabic. The MAN unbuttons his jacket, revealing... Clamped to his chest is a metal cage, locked with padlock and loaded with blocks of C4 wrapped in nails.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to the soldier) I'd need a seventy five meter perimeter. (to translator) Tell him to get on his knees and touch the sky. Get down! The translator SHOUTS. The man in the BLACK SUIT, gripped with despair, drops to his knees and raises his hands.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Can we just shoot him? As James considers that option when --

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: NO. He's not a bad man. He has a family. The bomb was forced on him. He is asking for help. Only help.  106

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to translator) I want you to get back. I got it. Sanborn pulls James aside for a private moment and pleads with him to be careful:

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: We've had our differences. Eldridge. It happened. That’s water under the bridge. But this -- this is suicide. James considers. Sanborn’s right, of course. But he can’t help himself. Like a moth to a flame, this is what he doe

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That's why it’s called a suicide bomb, right? Sanborn reluctantly seals James in the helmet. They bang fists.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE NEAR SUICIDE BOMBER
dialogues.text: James grabs a nearby soldier’s walkie, then starts the wa downrange. Soldiers moving back to their perimeter... PEDESTRIANS gathering for a look. Soldiers scattering the quickly. Black Suit smiles thinly as James nears. James nods at hi The man nods, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SUIT
dialogues.text: Inshalla. Inshalla.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Put your hands up!

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: He says he has a family, James kneels down to get a closer look at the bomb strapp to the man’s belly. He takes out his 9mm and puts it on t guy's forehead. Cocks the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Look, it would be a lot easier for me to disarm this if I just shoot you. Do you understand?  107 BLACK SUIT replies in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (into walkie) What is he saying?

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: (over walkie) He says, I don’t wish to die. I have a family. Please take this off me.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE NEAR SUICIDE BOMBER
dialogues.text: James holds his walkie up for the man to hear the transla

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) Tell him to put his hands behind his head or I will be very happy to shoot him. Translator conveys this to BLACK SUIT in Arabic. BLACK SU starts yelling in Arabic. Forehead wet with sweat.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: (over walkie) He says, please hurry he has a family.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to translator) Look, it’s not what I said. Tell him to put his hands behind his head or I will shoot him. James holds the walkie up to the man’s ear, “listen,” “do understand?” Now James sinks to his knees and examines the bomb, all t while keeping his pistol on the man’s head. There is a FOREST OF WIRES. He pushes them aside, revealing a cheap Casio digital WATCH, which is counting down from five minutes.  108

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) Sanborn, we got a timer. We got a lot of wires. I need a little help on this.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (over headset) Roger that, what do you need? James feels around the bomb. It’s strapped to the BLACK S man with heavy gauge metal. The man shakes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (headset) Bolt cutters. But you got two minutes to get down here.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (over walkie) Roger that. I'll be there in thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: HUMVEE
dialogues.text: Sanborn is already running towards the truck when he hear James.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE NEAR SUICIDE BOMBER
dialogues.text: James presses the man’s head to comfort him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to man) I know. Its’ okay. You’re alright. The Casio watch is at 4:30.

dialogues.speaker: UPRANGE FROM SUICIDE BOMBER
dialogues.text: Sanborn runs hard with the bolt cutters.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRANGE NEAR SUICIDE BOMBER
dialogues.text: Sanborn hands James the cutters. The man is crying. Sanborn sees the Casio. It reads 4:00  109

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: You weren't kidding.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Nope. James works the cutter blade. ECU: Bolt Cutter. It SCRAPES futilely against the metal.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (sotto) What is this made out of?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Case hardened steel. James doubles his effort. ECU: Bolt Cutter. The blade bites the steel, but it doesn give. James squeezes with all his might.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: What’s our time?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We'd need torch to get this off.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: We don’t have one of those in the truck. He’s a dead man. ECU: Casio Watch 1:46.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hold on let me think. We got this. I can handle it. I’m going to look at the back. Sanborn nods. His hand is starting to shake. James goes behind the man, and rips open the back of his shirt, revealing the back of the bomb. Here too it is a welded band, but the metal looks thinner James works it with the cutter. ECU: Casio Watch 1:30.  110

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We don’t have enough time, Sanborn. We don’t have enough time. I have to get these bolts off.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: We at a minute and a half, we got to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I'll handle this. Go.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Look, Will, come on --

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Fuck him, Come on, man. James --

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Sanborn you have forty five seconds. YOU HAVE FORTY FIVE

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: He’s a dead man, Will!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Go! Sanborn runs uprange.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: (shouting to soldiers)

dialogues.speaker: GET BACK
dialogues.text: The soldiers turn and run. James strains to clip the metal bar of the lock, putting of his weight into the effort. Finally, the blades slices ECU: broken lock falls to the ground. James sees that he has four more locks more to cut. The t is ticking down to 20 seconds. James brings himself face-to-face with the man he can’t s  111

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I can’t There’s too many locks. I can’t do it. I can’t get it off. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SUIT
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Please, please, please--

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. You hear me? I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SUIT
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Help me. Help me! James drops the bolt cutter, kneels down in front of the and shakes his head. That’s it. The man understands James’ gesture. He reaches forward, grabbing James’ suit.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SUIT
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) No! No! Please James brushes his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. James turns his back to the man and runs for cover. --James running, arms akimbo --The Black Suit man stands up and cries out to ALLAH!

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: -- He explodes and a hailstorm of particulate matter come flying at 22,000 feet per second straight at us -- chunks of molten metal hit James, knocking him to the ground --Sanborn, diving to keep the translator behind a barrier grazed by shrapnel.  112

dialogues.speaker: EXT DOWNRANGE/BLAST SITE
dialogues.text: James’ white face; blood seeps from his nose. Then as if overcoming great resistance his heart turns over with a l beating. And as Sanborn recovers and shouts orders, “everybody out” in the background, James opens his eyes t the sky. A KITE flutters overhead.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE DUSK
dialogues.text: The Humvee chugs through a crowded neighborhood. Traffic thickening. Shadows against a dimming sky.

dialogues.speaker: INT HUMVEE DUSK
dialogues.text: James drives. Sanborn is in the passenger seat covered in grime and dust.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No man. I hate this place James passes Sanborn some Gatorade.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Have a hit. Sanborn drinks, grateful, and puts the Gatorade down. The looks at James.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I’m not ready to die, James.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You're not going to die out here, bro. Sanborn shakes his head. Unconsciously, his fingers touch neck, finding the exposed area above the collar of his bo armor.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: Another two inches. Shrapnel goes zing -- slices my throat. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 SANBORN (cont'd) I bleed out like a pig in the sand. Nobody will give a shit. I mean my parents, they care, but they don’t count. Who else? (beat) I don’t even have a son.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You're going to have plenty of time for that.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No man, I’m done. (beat) I want a son. I want a little boy, Will. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: I mean, how do you do it? Take the risk?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I guess I don’t think about it.

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: But you know what I’m talking about, right? Every time we go out, you throw the dice. You recognize that, right?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah. I do. But I don’t know why. Do you know why -- I am the way I am? Sanborn thinks on this. After a beat -

dialogues.speaker: SANBORN
dialogues.text: No I don’t. They exchange a long look. Brothers at last.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HUMVEE
dialogues.text: A gang of laughing KIDS throw rocks at the armored Humvee

dialogues.speaker: INT KNOXVILLE, TENNESSEE SUPERMARKET MONTHS LATER
dialogues.text: We're walking with James down a wide, polished aisle, pas shelves of frozen treats glistening behind reflective gla in the shiny and perfectly sterile cathedral to consumeri otherwise known as a supermarket. James looks different here, awkward, less sure of himself With his hair grown-in and his dreamy expression, he coul just another suburban softy pushing a shopping cart. He’s home but this is clearly not where he lives. A beautiful young WOMAN approaches him from the other end the aisle. She too is pushing a shopping cart and in it i small BOY. She smiles at James and says:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Honey, will you grab some cereal and I'll meet you at the checkout. CONNIE JAMES smiles again and pats her husband on the shoulder. As she walks away, he mumbles:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Where’s the cereal? But she’s already out of ear shot.

dialogues.speaker: CEREAL AISLE
dialogues.text: James stares at the rows and rows of cereal boxes, a medl of different brands all containing the same sugar and coloring and starch. He looks this way and that. Thrown by the abundant choices after the starkness of Baghdad, he can’t decide which brand is his. He reaches for a box, then pulls back, still unsure of himself. Giving up, he picks a box at random and tosses it into th cart.  115

dialogues.speaker: DAYS LATER
dialogues.text: Rain water. Falling leaves. James is cleaning out the gut working under an overcast sky.

dialogues.speaker: INT KNOXVILLE JAMES HOUSE LIVING ROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: James zones out in front of a snowy TV; the glow plays on face.

dialogues.speaker: INT KNOXVILLE KITCHEN NEXT MORNING
dialogues.text: Domesticity. Connie peels a pile of carrots. James washes mushrooms in the sink. He tries to clean them individually but they crumble in h hands.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Some guy drove his truck into a middle of an Iraqi market. He starts passing out free candies. All the kids come running up - he detonates. (beat) They’re saying fifty nine dead... She's heard this kind of story before and knows where it ends. She can’t bring herself to reply.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You know they need more bomb techs.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (handing James the carrots) Will you chop these up for me?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES PRELAP
dialogues.text: Boing! Boing! Boing! INT JAMES' SON’S BEDROOM LATER THAT NIGHT Bedtime. James is putting his son to sleep in a room decorated with mobiles and colorful wall hangings. He set the mobile spinning.  116

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Boing! Boing! The boy giggles and reaches up. On the bed is a Jack-In-the-Box, which James picks up and winds. He opens the toy for his son who squeals with deli eyes wide with admiration for his daddy. Daddy, however, isn’t sure where to go with this..An odd moment for the w man of Baghdad: playing the awkward dad to his adoring ch James looks into his son’s unconditionally loving eyes. Something he sees there prompts a confession:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You love playing with that, don’t you..? You love all your stuffed animals. You love your Mommy, your Daddy. You love your pajamas... You love everything, don’t you? James playfully spins the mobile. The boy laughs at the whirring color.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: But you know what buddy, as you get older some of the things that you love might not seem so special anymore. You know? Like your Jack- in-the-Box. The boy touches the Jack-in-the-Box, smiling beautifully.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Maybe... you'll realize it’s just a piece of tin and a stuffed animal. And the older you get, the fewer things you really love. (beat) By the time you get to be my age, maybe it’s only one -- or two -- things. James pauses. His son continues to giggle and play.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: With me, I think it’s one.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAGHDAD TARMAC
dialogues.text: --sonic overload of a C-130 airplane landing. Wheels touch down on tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: INT EXT AIRPLANE
dialogues.text: The hydraulics of a loading ramp engage, lowering the ram and revealing a troop of young SOLDIERS inside the belly the plane. Passing over their frightened faces, we find one man who looks remarkably at ease. James. The soldiers disembark and we follow James as he leaves t plane and greets a another young EOD SOLDIER who has been waiting for him on the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Welcome to Delta-Company. James shakes his hand. A Middle-Eastern sun bathes James’ upturned face lengthen into a smile. His pace slows...the tarmac transitions to dirt as little puffs of dust lift off his continuous passage. He is now in the bomb suit and we are --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BAGHDAD OUTSKIRTS DAY
dialogues.text: On yet another war-torn street. Two fresh faced EOD SOLDIERS observe James as he makes another lonely walk down an empty block... heading to a b -- James' face glistening with pleasure -- The noon day sun shimmers on his helmet shield

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: DAYS LEFT IN DELTA COMPANY’S ROTATION: 365  118 And we watch him go down the unnamed road until he disappears.
